title: Are Huawei phones better than iPhones? - Quora

response.answer_text: Well, I have used both, let's see….. Price, MUCH better. The best that Huawei can offer is the P30 Pro, which costs 8990 Norwegian kr. The best that Apple can offer is the iPhone 11 Pro, which costs 16000 Norwegian kr. The phones are pretty much identical, though Apple may have tiny miscellaneous advantages. Any options to chop down the price? Huawei can offer you the P30 Lite, which will cut down battery power by 25, RAM from 8 to 6 GB, but lowers price to 2990 Norwegian kr, which is 30% of a Pro. Yes, I bought the Lite, and there are some problems, which are understandable since It’s cheap and should be worse. Huawei loses a big aspect to Apple, which is device capacity. Some games on Huawei are limited to 30 FPS, which is quite a bummer. The iPhones takes the crown, as they can offer 60FPS on almost everything. But, this is a hollow victory, as games will add 60 FPS to more devices, so sooner or later, Huawei will also gain 60 FPS, and this advantage will be gone. Another notch Huawei seizes is Battery capacity. (To make a fair fight, I’m comparing the iPhone X to the P30 Lite, as I couldn’t dig up capacity for the 11 yet.) The XR packs 2900 milliamps The Lite packs 3300 milliamps. They are quite the same, but Huawei has the edge. Wait, I found the iPhone 11 Pro capacity. Let’s do the proper comparison! The 11 Pro packs 3900 milliamps The P30 Pro packs 4200 milliamps. Thumbs up, both Apple and Huawei, that was a quite large improvement from one development! Again, they are quite similar, but Huawei has the edge. Another important aspect is storage, and it’s…….a mixed bag. It’s in Apple’s favor if you wanna toss money around, and in Huawei’s, if you need a cheap phone. Apple starts at 32 GB and 64 GB and ends at an Impressive 512 GB Huawei starts at 64 GB and ends at 256 GB. The P20 Lite has the lowest at 64 GB, but then, they are priced nearly the same (P30 Lite is 400 kr more expensive) as a P30 lite, so why not get the newer? So, if you are a rich son of the mayor, and need a humongous storage, the iPhones are the better, but if you are a college student scraping together money for a phone, the Huawei phones are better. Theoretically, Huawei is better, but they won’t gain much more former iPhone users unless Apple tragically fails them, or gets obviously behind on quality, which I honestly don’t think will happen. If I had mistaken anything, do please tell me.

In this matters, you have to regard all answers as personal opinions, some more technical, some more from the perspective of a simple user. I’m not a fan of any of the them, or any other manufactures or software house. What I can do is find the logical behind the way this two companies are managed and the core industrial strategy behind them. Please disregard any answer that’s to aggressively in defense of one or the other and never mind the childish persecution of Huawei by the USA administration. I suppose everybody can understand what’s behind this absurd claims (Apple also makes their phones in China). Both manufacturers are week established ones, with very good products. The advantage Apple has is the fax they developed a system, rather then just the hardware. They are able to perfect the fusion between software and hardware in a way that no other manufacturer can. The develop and test the bonding of the os with the equipments close to perfection. They are surely not the most innovative or revolutionary but what they implement normally becomes the industry standard regarding that same implementation. They are not in ““the lead”, they do not take many risks and they are have a very well thought off marketing strategy that’s been working for them, for ages. One additional point is the fact that they have a all ecosystem that involves softwares and all the hardware you use for work and leisure everyday, in a very integrated and easy way. They have MacBooks, imacs, iPads (and this is a implementation nobody could even get close to), iPhone, Apple Watch etc. Huawei (and all of there competitors) don’t have that (yet). They still rely on third party software and have to implant adaptation measures, filling the phones with bloatwate). Huawei makes great phones, with amazing cameras and good battery life. They are very good quality and if you don’t mind all that’s said above, and is not inside apples ecosystem, you cannot to wrong with Huawei. Apple and iPhones are just a world apart, not in terms of sheer quality or ““better of worse”, just very different. Ps: do you think Huawei could release a phone that’s 4/ 5 year old design and make it a sales success (iPhone SE 2)? No! It’s just another dimension of the same industry.

In terms of tech innovation, Huawei has come from behind to beat Apple.  Huawei launched its new big-screen flagship smartphone series, the Mate 30, in Berlin on Thursday. During the launch, the Chinese phone-maker bashed U.S. rival Apple for copying its iconic "bathroom heater-shaped" rear camera module on the Mate 20 series, and introduced a new round design which looks more like a standalone camera. In CGTN's Mate 20 X 5G review, we mentioned the possibility that iPhone 11's camera module design was inspired by Huawei. Watch the full review here and find out why the Mate 20 X still matters. The iPhone 11 series not only has a similar camera module to Mate 20, but an identical triple-camera setup: Main, telephoto and wide-angle cameras. Huawei claimed in 2018 they were the first to bring such a setup to a smartphone. The Mate 30 series In addition to the leaked information reported on Wednesday, Huawei revealed more details about the series. Screen: The Mate 30 Pro has a 6.53-inch screen with 88-degree double-curved edges. Huawei calls the design "Flex OLED," though it's more commonly known as "waterfall." The screen of Mate 30 is bigger than Mate 30 Pro, at 6.62 inches. Besides using it to replace the volume rockers, Huawei said it also added a camera shutter button on the edge, making it easier for users to take photos with one hand. Weight: The Mate 30 and Mate 30 Pro both weigh a little under 200 grams, about 88 percent of the iPhone 11 Pro Max. Yet Huawei's consumer product CEO Richard Yu said the Mate 30 has a longer battery life than Apple's product. Color options: In addition to traditional black, silver, purple and green, Huawei also added two "vegan leather" options. The green and orange leather will not break as easily as glass and is more skin-friendly. Chip: The Kirin 990 5G chip has already been made known to the public. Yu said the 5G version of the Mate 30 Pro can make use of the 5G network around the world, unlike Samsung's limited 5G capacity or iPhone 11's complete lack of 5G. Charging: Contrary to leaked information, the Mate 30 only supports 27 watt wireless charge, but the Mate 30 Pro can be charged wirelessly at a speed of 40 watts. Huawei also built in-car wired/wireless chargers for car owners to enjoy faster charging time. Camera: Huawei upgraded the triple-camera set to enable a 45-time zoom, from 30 in the P30 series. They also imported P30's RYYB sensor to the Mate series to let in more light in dark places. The sensor size is "137 percent" larger than the iPhone 11 Pro Max, according to Yu. The Mate 30 Pro takes one step further with higher specifications. Check the picture below for details. These enable the Mate 30 Pro to use night-shot and HDR functions on the wide-angle camera.  On the video side, Huawei said they have reached the "world's highest video light sensitivity on smartphone." Bokeh video can also be taken with the faster sensor and CPU. Huawei even challenged the GoPro on extreme sport videography. Source:Huawei bashes Apple for copying camera module design at Mate 30 launch

It is highly subjective, but if you take face-value alone, see for yourself: The iPhone XS-Max with 512GB storage (the best iPhone available) retails in the UK for £1,449. It has two cameras, with 2x optical zoom, at best at 12 megapixels, 6 CPU cores, 4GB RAM and a 3174mAh battery and a 6.5″ OLED 1242 x 2688 screenA Huawei P30 Pro with 512GB storage (arguably the best phone available) retails in the UK for £1,094. It has three cameras, with 5x optical zoom, at best 40 megapixels, an 8-core CPU, 8GB RAM and a 4200mAh battery, 6.47″ OLED 1080 x 2340 screenThe iPhone has half the RAM, 75% the battery capacity of the Huawei, and the Huawei camera setup is MILES better than anything else on the market, yet the iPhone is nearly 40% more expensive. Both the above phones are furiously fast, and the battery would easily last more than 24 hours in all cases, as you would expect for a top-of-the-line phone, but you get better bang-for-buck with the Huawei. Having owned and used devices from Apple, Samsung and Huawei, I can categorically state that my P20 Pro (last year’s model) is the best phone I have ever owned in almost every respect. The photos are breathtaking, the device NEVER slows down, and the battery reliably lasts more than 24 hours even with heavy use, and I have 80+ apps installed. I tried an iPhone for 6 months last year, and though it was fast, I was constantly frustrated by the poor usability and the lack of innovation. See my other post Are Samsung phones really as good as iPhones?. I suggest most new phones are good, so go with what you know (and can afford) unless you are prepared for the pain of switching and trying to migrate all your stuff across!!!

I have been an iPhone user for almost 6 years. My favorite phone (that I currently have) is the iPhone SE. I even find the iPhone 7 a little too large to easily hold in one hand and use comfortably. Once Apple discontinued the 3.5-inch screen size with iPhone SE and replaced the whole batch of iPhones with outrageously expensive models, I was so pissed that I started looking for an Android phone. There were no compact smartphones with 3.5 to 4-inch display sizes anymore and I purchased a Mi A2 Lite (that costs about 1/10th of the cost of an iPhone XS) with AndroidOne installed in it. The phone I tested at the shop was running Android version 8. After I purchased, I upgraded it to version 9. After the update, the phone started experiencing some lags while scrolling. Besides, Android doesn’t give the feeling that iOS gives. I can’t explain it well but there is something either wrong or missing. The Android settings are far more complicated than iOS. There are more features but they are complicated to set and for the first few days, you may not get them right. Your phone may not come out of the “do not disturb” mode or may vibrate while it is supposed to ring only. I was thinking that AnroidOne, which is the purest form of Android, would be better than some third party user interfaces (UIs) developed by the phone makers. I might have been mistaken. UIs developed by smartphone manufacturers for Android may actually give a better user experience but I recommend you to read all comments before you proceed with buying one. Because some users say those UIs don’t get as many updates as AndroidOne gets. So, you should definitely study before buying an Android. You have asked if you should get an iPhone or a Huawei but the answer I gave was all about the operating systems. In terms of hardware, you can’t go wrong with Huawei or Samsung. I tested many phones before I decided to buy this very affordable Mi A2 Lite and they were all great pieces of hardware. Even this Mi A2 Lite has 3-day battery life with a 5.84-inch screen. Now I use it as my Netflix remote at home and I do some browsing on it and its great. I charge once a week. Under daylight, it takes better photos than my iPhone SE. But iOS gives me a smoother user experience in my daily life. That’s why I replaced my iPhone SE’s battery and I am back on it.
